There are some places in the U.S. that are a waste of time for democrats to campaign in, and Kansas is one of them.

Did you see any of the poor coal miners in Kentucky being interviewed during the primary for the U.S. Senate race? They are all poor, unemployed, on food stamps and welfare, uninsured and uneducated. And they all despise Obama despite the fact that the Republicans vow to cut their food stamps, their welfare checks, and to repeal the Affordable Care Act. They are prototypical of much of the south and the mid-west in that they vote against their own economic interests.

This has been an ongoing phenomenon since before the civil war, when the rich plantation owners convinced poor white southerners that they should be politically aligned with rich white planters as opposed to poor blacks. In short, racism trumps class.

The rich have used race as a wedge successfully for years. A poor white southerner (and now poor and middle class whites from the mid-west and the south) will vote against their own economic interests in order to feel that they are still not at the bottom in society; they arewhite and therefore they are still considered better than blacks.

It's a mindset that has persisted for well over a century. And considering the small number of electoral votes at stake, it is easy to conclude that campaigning in Kansas is not a wise use of limited resources.

You obviously have a very limited experience with Europe. Ideological divisions and ethnic tensions here have not been so high since the Second World War. In France, delinquency is on the rise in the city AND in the country, non-electronic social networks are disintegrating, factories are closing, fields are going untilled and community trust is plummeting. It has declined in the six years I have lived here, but my friends who grew up in multiple regions have spoken of the even more dramatic changes over the last twenty years.

to rpmth. I never said that Scandinavian countries weren't more homogeneous than the US. You are correct and it does make many things easier for them. But, my point is I am tired of Americans saying that international comparisons are invalid because the US has unique, somehow insurmountable problems. I reject that notion. All other countries have (or have had) huge problems to overcome, which may be of a different character to those in the US but are nonetheless just as troublesome. You hint at this yourself by saying that ideological problems in Europe are not entirely in the past--you do raise a good point there (though I would say they are still not nearly at the level of the cold war or WWII)

It is true, one must not be to hastily dismissive of what someone else does simply because that person lives under different conditions. However, it is also important to consider whether said conditions might not in some cases be prerequisite to certain solutions.

"You hint at this yourself by saying that ideological problems in Europe are not entirely in the past--you do raise a good point there (though I would say they are still not nearly at the level of the cold war or WWII)"

Actually, most observers agree that at least in France at any rate society has never been so fragile since the end of World War II. Just wait until we run out of money to fund the dependants in the peripherary districts and the near-suburbs and then watch the sparks fly. It'll make the students strikes of 1968 seem like baby candy. And that will only be the beginning, and that subset of the population will only be the first to react.

It is absurd to compare the USA with small, lill-white, homogeneous Scandinavian countries. Compare the poverty rate, crime rate, education of say Vermont to Finland, and it is about the same. Conversely, introduce 12% of ex-slave black population and 15% hispanic legal and illegal immigrants into Finland and see how their society copes.

Also absurd is this notion that the US Government took losses from big-bank bailouts and protected the investors. Nothing could be further from the truth. The investors in Lehman, Bear Sterns for example were wiped out, and the US Gvmt actually made money in the bailout of the big private banks. It lost money bailing out Fannie Mae and Fredie Mac (government chartered financial institutions).

It is no longer enough to point out the debased state of the Economics profession, macroeconomics division. We need someone to shout out, Macroeconomic theory is worse than worthless, it is culpable.

It is no longer enough to continuously point to the iniquities inherent in our political/economic system. We know by now. We need, instead, someone to begin leading the discussion of what is to be done.

It is no longer enough to read our favorite liberal commentators in the comfort of our homes. We need instead to think, to converse, and most of all, to get out and organize.

We need a strong, engaged, left, a left dedicated to preserving the environment, and to compassion and justice for all. How can such a left emerge? I don't know. But I suggest that we look to our history, to the battles to unionize in the first half of the twentieth century, and the Montgomery bus boycott and the civil-rights movement from the second half of the twentieth century. These movements did not succeed by working within the system. They attacked the system.

The Rich thrive on helping confuse the general population about 'effective' tax rates (which is what is actually paid) and "marginal tax rates" which is what is paid on the last dollar taxed.

If you are rich, most of your income comes from long term capital gains (taxed at 15%) or dividends (taxed at rates significantly lower than the highest marginal income tax rate). If you own a vast amount of stock, simply take a loan out against it, live off the loan, and never pay taxes on the benefit in your lifetime.

Indeed, the high marginal tax rates tend to get applied to two-income households who have high incomes (and tend to work for a living), rather than those who inherited their money or enjoyed a windfall.

I had a different response to Prof. Stiglitz, to wit.

"It is simplistic to argue that our problems are political rather than economic, just as it would be simplistic to argue the converse. Stiglitz himself demonstrates this when he points out the essential circularity of the process, "Economic inequality translates into political inequality and political inequality yields increasing economic inequality."

Why does Stiglitz argue against himself in this fashion? Because he subscribes to the tired liberal belief that we can reform the system from within. But the essential truth is that our political/economic process is broken beyond repair. Only a vigorous left can hope to right the ship. Unfortunately we barely have a center, let alone a left of any sort.

What would a vigorous left look like, and how can we get there from here? Frankly, I'm not sure. What I am sure of is that we must find a way to shift the discussion, we must search for radical alternatives to business/politics as usual.

One suggestion; look to the early struggles to unionize and the Montgomery bus boycott for inspiration. The beauty of boycotts is that they involve people in ways that fundamentally change the participants. For it is certain that, to change our system, we must change ourselves. Boycotts can help us to to harness the enormous power we have as consumers, if only we are willing utilize it.

Use boycotts to organize. Organize to change.
